keywords.value: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
keywords.name: subject

byline.contributor: Sam Borden contributed reporting from Paris; James Montague from Utrecht, the Netherlands; and Kareem Fahim from Los Angeles.

lead_paragraph: Critics want to know if Sheikh Salman bin Ebrahim al-Khalifa had any connection to the jailing and torture of Bahraini athletes who protested his family’s rule in 2011.

headline.print_headline: Shadow of Human Rights Abuse Follows Contender in FIFA Vote
headline.main: Shadow of Human Rights Abuse Follows Contender in FIFA Vote

snippet: Critics want to know if Sheikh Salman bin Ebrahim al-Khalifa had any connection to the jailing and torture of Bahraini athletes who protested his family’s rule in 2011.
abstract: Sheikh Salman bin Ebrahim al-Khalifa of Bahrain is one of favorite contenders to replace Sepp Blatter as president of FIFA, but calls by critics to investigate whether he was involved with suppressing Bahraini athletes who protested his family's rule in 2011 could complicate bid; accusations against Sheikh Salman are problematic for organization, which is trying to project image of reform in wake of bribery and corruption charges filed against Blatter and other officials.
